awd_titl_txt: Exploring Thermally-Driven Occupant Behavior in Immersive Virtual Environments to Enhance the Design and Engineering of Sustainable Buildings
awd_abstract_narration:
Buildings are a major consumer of energy in the U.S.  The goal of this research is to create a human-centered design and engineering environment for sustainable buildings where occupant thermal state (sensation, comfort and acceptability) and thermally-driven behaviors are effectively measured to reduce building performance gaps between predicted and actual energy performance. Specifically, this project examines if immersive virtual environments (IVEs) integrated within a climate chamber, i.e., multi-sensory IVEs, are effective for observing thermally-driven occupant behavior and for improving models of human-building interactions. The findings could result in new and effective strategies for reducing energy consumption in buildings. 

Building on pilot studies by the PIs, this project will: 1) determine if the virtual experience of participants significantly alters their thermal states and thermally-driven behaviors compared to in-situ experience; 2) determine if seasonal mismatch of immersive virtual environment and actual environment (i.e., simulating winter during summer data collection) significantly alters the thermal state and thermally-driven occupant behaviors compared to those in seasonally matched IVE conditions; and 3) create a mechanism of sharing IVE data and analytics on the virtual information fabric infrastructure (VIFI) platform to support the replication of science in a large multi-institutional research community. Currently, designers and engineers rely on predictive models based on data from existing buildings to make decisions about future building designs. When the impact of context on occupants is ignored, performance gaps emerge between the projected and actual energy performance of a building. Evidence from both academic research and practice strongly suggests that IVEs are capable of eliciting human responses to well-designed stimuli such as in lighting
design, but conventional IVEs alone cannot simulate cooling or heating as in real buildings. Climate chambers have long been used as a reliable apparatus for studying occupant thermal states, but they cannot easily induce occupant behavior in response to design contexts. Multi-sensory IVEs combine the strength of IVEs and climate chambers, but the effectiveness of multi-sensory IVEs to produce comparable thermal state and thermally-driven occupant behavior as in-situ experiments is unknown. This new knowledge will enable the creation of context-sensitive, human-centered approaches using multi-sensory IVEs for building design and engineering, and occupant behavior data collection. Sustainable buildings are essential for sustaining the wellbeing of individuals, families and the society. Buildings consume more than 30% of the world's primary energy, largely for providing thermal comfort. A better understanding of occupant's thermally-driven occupant behavior during design is thus critical tosustainable buildings. Multi-sensory IVEs not only provide a new tool to support the design and engineering of sustainable buildings, but also present intellectual challenges to other scientific fields. To maximize the impact of this research, the PIs will create a novel approach for data sharing and research replication by collaborating with researchers in the VIFI team, a research coordination network called sustainable human-building ecosystems (SHBE), as well as with technical committees of ASHRAE.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) awarded this grant to Louisiana State University (LSU) in 2018 to investigate if immersive virtual environments (IVEs) integrated within a climate chamber, i.e., multi-sensory IVEs, are effective for observing thermally-driven occupant behavior and modeling human-building interactions. A multidisciplinary team of researchers at LSU collaborated with scientists at the DOE's Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory to design the research protocol. The researchers conducted a series of controlled experiments involving 138 individuals on the LSU campus. The analysis focuses on using thermal state votes (e.g., thermal sensation, thermal comfort, and thermal acceptability), physiological responses (e.g., heart rate and skin temperature), and behavioral intentions to investigate the effectiveness of IVE-based experiments.

To determine if the virtual experience of participants significantly alters their thermal states and thermally-driven behaviors compared to in-situ experiences, the researchers conducted different analyses on the collected data. First, the analyses on thermal state votes showed that participants' thermal experiences, in general, were not significantly altered by their virtual experiences. However, analyses of physiological measures (to measure thermal experiences) produced less consistent results than those of thermal state votes when comparing IVE and in-situ experiments. Secondly, analyses on thermally-driven behavior, measured by behavior intentions, showed that the thermal vote differences of the participants could not solely explain intentional differences between IVE and in-situ experimental settings. Finally, the participants' virtual experience factors, such as their immersion, presence, and cybersickness, were not the causing factors of thermal states and behavioral intentions when they were controlled. However, participants' behavioral factors, such as their attitudes toward energy conservation and perceived behavioral control to conserve energy, were the causing factors of their behavioral intentions.

The variances observed in thermal and behavioral intention votes and physiological responses between IVE and in-situ experimental settings triggered researchers to further investigate the possible impact of visual stimuli and fluctuations in control conditions. One study investigating the visual impact of green walls on thermal comfort reconfirmed the need to ensure comparable visual stimuli in virtual experiments and control the exposure time of virtual experience (particularly when using head-mounted display devices). A time series analysis was performed to understand the impact of temperature fluctuations in the chamber on thermal state votes, physiological responses, and behavior intention responses. The results indicate that various time series factors are associated with the participants' thermal sensation, acceptability, comfort, and behavioral intention differences between virtual and real environments, including differences in the timing of peak and trough occurrence in relation to the vote response, differences in the total time of bursts, and variations in irregular patterns of indoor air and skin temperature between IVE and in-situ environments. 

The researchers further investigated the impact of outdoor temperature conditions on thermal state votes. Results showed that under the experimental and outdoor temperature conditions, outdoor temperature variations, in most cases, did not impact the results of IVE experiments. In addition, the participant's thermal sensation vote was found to be a reliable indicator between IVE and in situ settings in all studied conditions. A few significantly different cases were related to thermal comfort, thermal acceptability, and overall skin temperature.

The researchers created ontology-based metadata to support research on IVE-based experiments and data sharing. The virtual human-building interaction experimentation ontology (VHBIEO), an ontology extending the ontology of scientific experiments (EXPO), was created to standardize virtual human-building interaction experimentation. VHBIEO-based metadata can support sharing IVE data and analytics and replicating IVE-based experiments in a large research community. VHBIEO-based metadata was tested to share sample data on Dataverse.

In addition to research activities, the project impacted four Ph.D. dissertations, one Master thesis, and the work of two other graduate students. Relevant course materials were created and taught in the Building Information Modeling course, focusing on fusing human perceptual and behavioral responses into building performance analysis using virtual reality technologies. Collaboration with a local middle school serving disadvantaged communities, the Kenilworth Science & Technology School, provided mentorship opportunities for students from underrepresented backgrounds engaging in supervised research. The researchers conducted a webinar, invited lectures, talks/presentations, and a short course in addition to publications in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings. In addition, the researchers are actively involved in the IEA Annex 79, promoting the development of IVE-based solutions. The research infrastructure created on the campus, e.g., the climate chamber, was utilized by other faculty to conduct innovative research projects.

In summary, the researchers confirmed the potential and limitations of IVE-based experiments for collecting thermal-related data. Key experimental protocol factors were investigated to improve experimental efficacy. The enhancement of experimental protocol can be accelerated if more researchers share their experimental design and results enabled by the ontology-based metadata. Fusing human perceptional and behavioral data during design may significantly enhance designers' ability to understand and model human-building interactions for energy efficiency and human health & well-being.
